content.description: An easy endurance route. Start on the horn at the left side of the pit and traverse on positive features into a technical corner. Reach an enormous rounded jug and then follow the vertical crack.
content.protection: A crashpad on the rock bellow the Slicksides crack.
content.location: Start on the Slicksides Pit Traverse and join the Slicksides crack at the enormous rounded jug.

content.description: Move up the less steep face to the left of Lunge or Plunge through blocky, uninspiring holds.
content.location: Slicksides Pit, left of Lunge or Plunge at the far left of the climbable rock.

content.description: Climb the crack starting in the pit. An old school toprope problem.Â
content.protection: Two pads, cover up and ankle-breaker rock right at the base.
content.location: The obvious vertical crack in the Slicksides pit.

content.description: That's right, traverse the whole pit. Left to right, or right to left.
content.protection: Use your skillz. Or a pad.
content.location: Slicksides Pit. Traverse just above the ground, or as you like.
The right angling crack to the left of Slicksides crack.

content.description: On the right side of the "cove" (the back/right side of the Slicksides pit) is this slippery, technical testpiece. Slick feet and edges lead to a slopey slap and a tough topout. Very fun!
content.protection: One pad, it's a nice flat landing.
content.location: To the right of Digitalis and right of Fun Unnamed Problem.

content.protection: At least two pads and a good spot.

content.description:
I actually have no idea what the grade is for this problem. It starts to the right of Slicksides crack, and to the left of the prow, at the usual start of Slicksides. Move up, left, and up, but more or less directly up, without using the Slicksides crack. 

  Report back and let me know how hard/good you feel that this line is.
content.protection: Couple of pads and a spotter.

content.description: this is a route called Digitalis Prow a V5 it starts under the overhang moves out onto the tip of the nose with a right heel hook you throw for the dishy jug.
content.protection: Two pads and a good spotter.
content.location: The face, to the right of the overhanging prow, about 12 feet to the right of the Slicksides start.

content.description: To the right of Digitalis on the left of a short face, scramble up blocky large holds easily.
content.location: Back in the "cove," the right side of the Slicksides pit.

content.description: Sit Start with Right hand on the sloper side pull and left hand on the crimp. Go up using anything between the two vertical cracks that run from the ground to the top. Both vertical cracks are off.
content.location: On the right side of the Slicklides Pit. Right of Digitalis Pit Left (Fun Unnamed Problem)

content.description: The Slicksides Pit is one of the most unique climbing formations in the park, a giant Pothole 15 feet deep. It hold several classic highball boulder problems which are more frequently top-roped. Slidesides is a deviously slippery and challenging V0, next to the thrilling Lunge Or Plunge (V4).
